[[Louisiana blues]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[guitarist]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = | label = [[Excello Records|Excello]], [[Arhoolie Records|Arhoolie]], [[Blue Horizon]], [[Flyright Records|Flyright]] | associated_acts = | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Silas Hogan''' (September 15, 1911 – January 9, 1994) was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[musician]]. Hogan most notably recorded "Airport Blues" and "Lonesome La La", was the [[Lead vocalist|front man]] of the Rhythm Ramblers, and became an inductee in the Louisiana Blues Hall of Fame. ==Biography== Hogan learned guitar playing as a teenager and was performing on a regular basis by the late 1930s. Similar to [[Lazy Lester]] and [[Slim Harpo]], Hogan was influenced by [[Jimmy Reed]].{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | page= 76 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} He had relocated to [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana]] by the early 1950s, and equipped with a [[Fender Musical Instruments Corporation|Fender]] [[electric guitar]], Hogan put together the Rhythm Ramblers.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/silas-hogan-mn0000032767/biography |title=Silas Hogan | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}} They assisted in the development of the Baton Rouge Blues sound, and with band members Hogan (guitar), Isaiah Chapman (lead guitar), Jimmy Dotson (drums), plus Sylvester Buckley (harmonica), they stayed together for almost ten years. In 1962, by which time he was aged 51, Hogan was belatedly introduced by Harpo to the [[Crowley, Louisiana]] based [[record producer]], [[J. D. "Jay" Miller]]. Miller, via the offices of [[Excello Records]], started Hogan's recording career, at a time when interest in variations of swamp blues was starting to wane. Hogan did nevertheless see the issue of several singles up to 1965, when Miller's disagreement with the record label's new owners brought the [[recording contract]] to a swift finale. On some of his recordings, Hogan was backed by the [[harmonica]] player, [[Moses "Whispering" Smith]].{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/trouble-mw0000850928/credits |title=Trouble - Silas Hogan | Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}} Hogan had to disband the group, and returned to his full-time job at the [[ExxonMobile|Exxon]] [[oil refinery]]. In the late 1970s, Hogan recorded further tracks with both [[Arhoolie Records|Arhoolie]] and [[Blue Horizon]]. Hogan died in January 1994 of [[heart disease]], at the age of 82.{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1995.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 1994 - 1995 |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !Title !Label |- |1965 |''Trouble at Home'' |[[Blue Horizon]] |- |1972 |''Trouble'' |[[Excello Records|Excello]] |- |1989 |''I'm a Free Hearted Man'' |[[Flyright Records|Flyright]] |- |1995 |''So Long Blues'' |[[Ace Records (US)|Ace]] |- |1999 |''The Godfather'' |Wolf Records |}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/silas-hogan-mn0000032767/discography |title=Silas Hogan | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}} ===Compilation albums=== {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !Title !Label !Song by Hogan |- |1976 |''Gonna Head for Home'' |[[Flyright Records|Flyright]] |"I'm a Free-Hearted Man" |- |1976 |''Rooster Crowed for Day'' |[[Flyright Records|Flyright]] |"My Baby Walked Out", "Tell Me Baby" |- |1999 |''The Excello Story, Vol. 4: 1961-1975'' |Hip-O Records |"Trouble at Home Blues" |- |2002 |''Genuine Excello R&B'' |[[Ace Records (US)|Ace]] |"Go on Pretty Baby" |}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-excello-story-vol-4-1961-1975-mw0000237539 |title=The Excello Story, Vol. 4: 1961-1975 -
